transcript:
Patient: That covers everything I wanted to focus on today. I'm ready to dive in.

Therapist: Great, let's start by reviewing your homework from the last session. You mentioned that you've been practicing thought records and behavioral experiments. Can you tell me more about your experience with those exercises?

Patient: Well, I've been trying to do the thought records every day, like we discussed. It's been helpful to write down my negative thoughts and try to challenge them. But sometimes I get stuck and can't think of any evidence to counter the negative thoughts.

Therapist: That's a common challenge, Samir. It's okay if you can't always find evidence to counter the negative thoughts right away. The important thing is that you're practicing the skill of recognizing and questioning those thoughts. With time and practice, it will become easier to find balancing evidence. Can you give me an example of a thought record you completed recently?

Patient: Sure. The other day at work, I made a small mistake on a project, and my first thought was "I'm such a failure. I can't do anything right." I wrote that down and tried to challenge it. I remembered the compliment my supervisor gave me last week, so I wrote that down as evidence against the negative thought. But I still couldn't shake the feeling that I'm not good enough.

Therapist: You did a great job recognizing that negative thought and challenging it with evidence, Samir. It's okay if the feelings don't go away immediately. Challenging negative thoughts is a process, and it takes time for our emotions to catch up with our new way of thinking. Let's look at that thought record together and see if we can find more evidence to support a balanced thought.

Patient: Okay, that sounds good.

Therapist: In addition to your supervisor's compliment, what other evidence do you have that you're capable and competent at work?

Patient: Well, I've been entrusted with more responsibilities lately, and I've been able to handle them. And I've received positive feedback from coworkers on my contributions to team projects.

Therapist: That's great evidence, Samir! It shows that you're valued and respected at work, despite the occasional mistake. Everyone makes mistakes sometimes; it's part of being human and doesn't define your worth or competence. Based on this evidence, what would be a more balanced thought about your work performance?

Patient: I guess a more balanced thought would be "I'm capable and competent at work, even though I make mistakes sometimes. My value isn't defined by my mistakes."

Therapist: That's a much more balanced and realistic thought, Samir. I'm proud of you for challenging that negative thought and coming up with a healthier perspective. Let's keep practicing this skill together. Can you tell me about another negative thought you've had recently, either about work or another area of your life?

Patient: One thought that keeps coming up is "I'll never be able to have close relationships because I'm too awkward and quiet." I tried to challenge it, but I couldn't think of any evidence against it.

Therapist: That's a tough thought to challenge, Samir, but I believe we can find some evidence against it if we look closely. Let's start by examining the belief that being quiet and awkward means you can't have close relationships. Is that always true? Can you think of any examples of quiet or awkward people who have close relationships?

Patient: I guess it's not always true. One of my coworkers is pretty quiet, but he seems to have close friendships. And I've seen people in my religious community who are a bit awkward but still have strong connections with others.

Therapist: That's great evidence that being quiet or awkward doesn't necessarily prevent someone from having close relationships. Now let's look at your own experiences. Have there been times when you've felt connected to others, even if you were quiet or felt awkward?

Patient: Well, I've had some good conversations with people at my religious community center. And I've felt close to my hiking buddies, even though we don't talk much on the trails.

Therapist: Those are great examples, Samir! They show that you're capable of forming connections with others, even if you're quiet or feel awkward at times. It's not about being the most outgoing or charismatic person; it's about finding people who appreciate you for who you are. Based on this evidence, what would be a more balanced thought about your ability to have close relationships?

Patient: I guess a more balanced thought would be "Being quiet or awkward doesn't mean I can't have close relationships. I've had meaningful connections with people who appreciate me for who I am."

Therapist: That's a much more balanced and hopeful thought, Samir. I'm glad we could find evidence to challenge that negative belief. As we continue practicing thought records, I think you'll find it easier to come up with balancing evidence and more helpful thoughts. Remember, the goal isn't to get rid of negative thoughts completely, but to develop a more balanced and realistic perspective.

Patient: That makes sense. I'll keep practicing the thought records and try to remember the evidence we found today.

Therapist: That's great, Samir. I'm proud of the progress you're making. In addition to the thought records, you mentioned that you did a behavioral experiment related to a social situation. Can you tell me more about that experience?

Patient: Yeah, I went to a social event at my religious community center, like we planned. I was really nervous beforehand, and I almost didn't go. But I reminded myself that it was an experiment, and I wanted to see what would happen.

Therapist: It's great that you pushed yourself to go, even though you were nervous. That takes a lot of courage. What happened at the event?

Patient: At first, I felt really awkward and out of place. I didn't know many people there, and I wasn't sure how to start conversations. But then someone came up to me and started talking about the recent sermon, and we had a really good discussion. I ended up talking to a few different people throughout the night, and I even made plans to go hiking with one of them next weekend.

Therapist: That's wonderful, Samir! It sounds like the experiment was a success. Even though you felt awkward at first, you were able to have meaningful conversations and even make plans with someone. What did you learn from this experiment?

Patient: I learned that even if I feel awkward or out of place at first, I can still connect with people and have a good time. And I realized that people at my religious community center are really welcoming and open to talking to new people.

Therapist: Those are great insights, Samir. It's so important to challenge our negative predictions and assumptions through experiments like this. The more you put yourself in social situations and have positive experiences, the more your confidence will grow. I'm really proud of you for taking this step.

Patient: Thanks, Nova. I'm glad I did it, even though it was scary at first. I feel a little more hopeful about making friends and connections now.

Therapist: That's great to hear, Samir. I'm glad you're feeling more hopeful. As we continue to do behavioral experiments and practice social skills, I think you'll find it easier and easier to connect with others and build the relationships you want.
